data.title: Women Who Drum, RnB Rib Music Festival, more events in Detroit
data.meta_description: Immerse yourself in Shakespearean drama, dance to drum performances, eat barbecue and find more fun events in Detroit this week, Aug. 7-14.
data.text:
Hey Detroiters! This week, weâ€™re relaxing on the sandy shores of Campus Martius and dancing to the soulful beats at Hart Plaza as we connect and thrive together.

Whether youâ€™re looking to meet up with us for coffee at Cred Cafe, groove to yacht rock tunes or immerse yourself in a Shakespearean drama, this weekâ€™s brimming with excitement. Weâ€™ve got family-friendly events like Reading and Rhythm on the Riverfront, a tribute to local legend Rodriguez and even a House Music Picnic and a Hip-Hop Block Party to wrap up your weekend with a bang.

So, stay tuned, stay engaged and most importantly, get out there and Get Busy!

Thursday

â˜• Join the Outlier Team for Coffee Thursday at Cred Cafe on Jefferson Avenue. Come grab a coffee or tea (our treat!) and tell our team whatâ€™s happening in your neighborhood. Free.

ğŸ“š Bring your kiddo(s) to Gabriel Richard Park for Reading and Rhythm on the Riverfront. Those who come to the event will get the chance to choose a book from Detroit Public Libraryâ€™s Library on Wheels. Free. Registration required.

ğŸ›¥ï¸ Groove out on the sandy beaches of, uh, Campus Martius for the Yacht Rock Beach Party. The Leaky Tikis will be performing, and wear your best Hawaiian shirts and captainâ€™s hats, as there are prizes for the best yacht rock outfits. Prizes, plus live music, plus downtown beach equals fabulous! Free.

ğŸ’ Pop over to Eastern Market for Creative Mornings Detroitâ€™s pop-up, Summer in the Market! A shake-up of its usual early-morning programming, this special social event is in the evening and will be hosted by local businesses along Gratiot Avenue, including Handcar, La Ventana Cafe, Detroit Beer Co. and Flowers for Dreams. Grab your best friends for some delicious food on a (hopefully) beautiful summer evening. Registration required. Free.

This weekend

ğŸ¶ Honor a Detroit-born musician at Remembering Rodriguez on Friday at Trinosophes in Eastern Market. The tribute concert, hosted by his family and friends, will feature the late singer-songwriterâ€™s songs played by local musicians who knew him. If youâ€™re not familiar, Rodriguez led a quiet life in Detroit, unaware that he was Elvis-level famous in Australia, New Zealand and South Africa. $10 suggested donation.

ğŸ“š Watch local authors and illustrators receive awards for their work with Eastside Community Network at Photovoice: Community Book Reading on Saturday at The Stoudamire. In addition to the awards, the authors and illustrators will do a childrenâ€™s book reading, and attendees will receive copies of the books. Registration required. Free, but donations are encouraged.

ğŸ– Get your three-day fill of barbecue and bodacious beats this weekend at the Ribs RnB Music Festival in Hart Plaza. Next, Troop, Ro James, Adina Howard and Glenn Jones will bring the rhythm and blues while barbecue lovers dine on the best ribs Detroit has to offer. Get there early for free entry. $0-15, free for ages 0-13.

ğŸª• Spend your Saturday celebrating Middle Eastern arts, food and music in Palmer Park at Freedom Arts Festival. Hosted at Palmer Parkâ€™s log cabin, the program features art from Southwest Detroit muralist Elton Monroy DurÃ¡n, multi-instrumentalist Victor Ghannam of the National Arab Orchestra and an incredible array of musical talent. Free.

ğŸ­ Enjoy Shakespeare in Detroitâ€™s performance of William Shakespeareâ€™s â€œJulius Caesarâ€ in Clark Park on Saturday. Directed by Asia Mark, the play marks the end of Shakespeare in Detroitâ€™s youth program season and will feature the technical and creative work of its students. Be sure to grab your picnic blankets! Free.

ğŸµï¸ Get hands on with Teaching Artist Stephanie Mae Howells at the Mindfulness Botanical Illustration Workshop at Griffin Gardens on Saturday. Feast your eyes on beautiful plants, render them on your canvas and practice some mindfulness techniques. Supplies provided. Registration required. $10.

ğŸ¥ Feeling rhythmic? Check out the Women Who Drum Festival on Sunday at Black Bottom Park in Milwaukee Junction. See if you can catch the beat with drummers Allison Miller, Camellia Akhamie Kies and Sarah Whitaker. Maybe bring some earplugs too. Free.

ğŸ›ï¸ Kick it on Belle Isle with the Women of â€œWine Downâ€ at the House Music Picnic on Sunday. DJs Bruce Bailey, Boxx and Jesus Martinez are on the turntables to bring some old-fashion partying to the isle. Bring your own food, drinks and friends. To sync with the crew, head to Shelter 19. Free.

ğŸ•ºğŸ¾ As if the weekend couldnâ€™t get any more fun! After you finish bumping to house music, join Class Act Detroit on Sunday for their annual Hip-Hop Block Party on 28th Street. Learn the Tamia hustle (finally), play games (donâ€™t lose at Spades!) and enjoy live performances by ZLight, Bred, City of Groove, and more. Oh and there will be school supply giveaways, just in time for the kiddos to head back. Free.

Next week

ğŸŒ‡ Party like itâ€™s Saturday night on Tuesday at Northern Lights Lounge with Global Sunsets. We canâ€™t wait to listen to jazzy jams from The Black Man & Arnold Trio while the sun sets over the Motor City. 21+. Free.

ğŸ¤ Share your verses at Poetry in the Park at Rock Local Entertainment Cafe in Highland Park. Sign up at the front desk to share your style with the crowd. Got stage fright this week? The event returns on select Wednesdays and Saturdays through August. $10.
